raw_text:
Wada will appeal against ruling
 
 The World Anti-Doping Agency (Wada) will appeal against the acquittal of Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou on doping charges, if the IAAF does not.
 
 The pair were cleared of charges relating to missing dope tests by the Greek Athletics Federation last week. Wada chairman Dick Pound said: "I am convinced the IAAF will appeal against the decision, and we will support them. "But if they accept the federation's ruling we will go before the Court of Arbitration for Sport," he added. Kenteris's lawyer, Gregory Ioannidis, reacted angrily to Pound's comments. "Comments like these only help to embarrass the sporting governing bodies, create a hostage situation for the IAAF and strengthen our case further," he told BBC Sport. Kenteris, 31, and Thanou, 30, had been charged with avoiding drugs tests in Tel Aviv, Chicago and Athens and failing to notify anti-doping officials of their whereabouts before the Olympics. They withdrew from the Athens Games after missing a drugs test at the Olympic village on 12 August.
 
 But an independent tribunal ruled that the duo had not been informed that they needed to attend a drugs test in Athens.
 
 However, their former coach Christos Tzekos was banned for four years by the tribunal. Kenteris and Thanou still have to face trial on charges brought separately by Greek prosecutors of missing the drugs tests and faking a motorcycle accident to avoid testing at the Athens Games.
llama3.2:1b: Wada will appeal against the ruling that cleared Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou of doping charges if the IAAF doesn't. Wada chairman Dick Pound says they will support the IAAF's decision unless it accepts the federation's ruling. The IAAF had allowed them to withdraw from the Athens Games after missing a drugs test, but an independent tribunal found that they were not informed and therefore could not have been banned for doping.
llama3.2:3b: Wada will appeal against the acquittal of Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou if the IAAF does not, following an independent tribunal's ruling that they were not informed about a required drug test in Athens.
gemma2:2b: WADA will appeal the acquittal of Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou if the IAAF does not. The pair were cleared of doping charges related to missed drug tests, but WADA is appealing due to their absence from doping tests in various locations before the Olympics, according to WADA's chairman Dick Pound. Their lawyer disagrees with this statement, claiming that it helps their case. Kenteris and Thanou still face separate trials for missing tests and faking an accident to avoid testing at the Athens Games.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Wada will appeal against the acquittal of Kostas Kenteris, Katerina Thanou and their former coach. If IAAF does not appeal, Wada will support their decision. The pair were cleared of doping charges related to missing dope tests but have since been charged with failing to notify anti-doping officials before the Olympics.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou will appeal against their World Anti-Doping Agency (Wada) acquittal, unless the IAAF appeals first. Wada chairman Dick Pound supports an appeal by the IAAF if it does not. Kenteris's lawyer reacts angrily to Pound's comments. The duo were cleared of doping charges but faced separate prosecution for missing drug tests and faking an accident.
qwen2.5:3b: Wada will appeal against the acquittal of Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou if the IAAF does not. The pair were cleared for missing dope tests by the Greek Athletics Federation but an independent tribunal ruled they had not been informed about a test in Athens. Wada's chairman Dick Pound said they would support the IAAF or appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Kenteris' lawyer criticized Pound's comments, suggesting they only help further their case. However, former coach Christos Tzekos was banned for four years by the tribunal. Kenteris and Thanou still face trial on separate charges brought by Greek prosecutors for missing tests and fake accident avoidance.
opencoder:1.5b:
The World Anti-Doping Agency (Wada) will appeal against the acquittal of Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou on doping charges, if the IAAF does not.
The pair were cleared of charges relating to missing dope tests by the Greek Athletics Federation last week. Wada chairman Dick Pound said: "I am convinced the IAAF will appeal against the decision, and we will support them." But if they accept the federation's ruling we will go before the Court of Arbitration for Sport.
Kenteris's lawyer, Gregory Ioannidis, reacted angrily to Pound's comments. "Comments like these only help to embarrass the sporting governing bodies, create a hostage situation for the IAAF and strengthen our case further," he told BBC Sport. Kenteris had been charged with avoiding drugs tests in Tel Aviv, Chicago and Athens and failing to notify anti-doping officials of their whereabouts before the Olympics.
The duo had not been informed that they needed to attend a drugs test in Athens. An independent tribunal ruled that the duo had not been informed, and therefore had not failed to test for drugs in the athlete's previous home city, which was then named after them. The tribunal upheld this finding and granted them their rights of trial on charges brought separately by Greek prosecutors.
However, their former coach Christos Tzekos was banned for four years by the tribunal.
smollm:1.7b: The summary is: Wada will appeal against ruling if IAAF does not, if Wada chairman Dick Pound says they will appeal against the decision, and if they accept the federation's ruling we will support them. The pair were cleared of doping charges by Greek authorities last week. If they accept the federation's ruling we will go before the Court of Arbitration for Sport to support them. Kenteris's lawyer said: "Comments like these only help to embarrass the sporting governing bodies, create a hostage situation for the IAAF and strengthen our case further."
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text as concisely as possible while preserving key ideas and details. Let me read through it carefully first.

The main points are: Wada is appealing against Kenteris and Thanou's acquittal for doping charges. They were cleared of those by the Greek Athletics Federation last week, but the IAAF hasn't yet agreed to their appeal. The pair faced drug tests in Tel Aviv, Chicago, and Athens before the Olympics. They withdrew from the Athens Games due to missing a test there on August 12th. An independent tribunal ruled they weren't informed about needing to attend the test, but they were banned by another tribunal for four years while still facing their own trials.

I should focus on the key actions: Wada's appeal, their drug tests at the Olympics, the IAAF's response, the former coach's ban, and the ongoing trials. Also, mention that the IAAF hasn't made a decision yet.
</think>

Wada is appealing against the acquittal of Kenteris and Thanou for doping charges, pending an appeal from the IAAF. The pair were cleared last week but faced drug tests at the Olympics in Tel Aviv, Chicago, and Athens. They withdrew from the Athens Games due to missing a test there on August 12th. An independent tribunal ruled they weren't informed about needing to attend the test, but another tribunal banned Christos Tzekos for four years while both continue trial on drug testing charges.
tinyllama:1.1b: Wada will appeal against the acquittal of Kostas Kenteri and Katerinia Thanou, as their former coach Christos Tzekos has been banned for four years by an independent tribunal. The IAAF will defend Wada's decision to acquit the pair in a bid to appeal against their clearance from charges of missing drug tests. Despite initial doubts about the validity of the Athens Games, the Athens Organising Committee and IAAF continue to argue for Wada's integrity.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Wada, which is the World Anti-Doping Agency, plans to appeal against the acquittal of two athletes from Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou, if the IAAF does not, according to IAAF chairman Dick Pound. However, if the IAAF does accept Wada's decision, Wada will proceed with their case against the IAAF.
phi:2.7b: Wada will appeal against the acquittal of two athletes from Greece who were cleared of doping charges related to missing dope tests, if not supported by IAAF. The pair's former coach was banned for four years. They still have to face trial on separate charges brought by Greek prosecutors.
orca-mini:3b: Wada will appeal against the ruling clearing Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou of doping charges, if the IAAF does not.
hermes3:3b: Wada plans to appeal against acquittal of Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou for doping charges, if IAAF accepts Greek Athletics Federation's ruling; otherwise Wada will appeal to Court of Arbitration for Sport.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: WADA plans to appeal against the acquittal of Greek athletes Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou, who were acquitted last week by the Greek Athletics Federation of doping charges relating to missing dope tests. WADA chairman Dick Pound believes the IAAF will also appeal, but if they don't, Kenteris and Thanou will go before the Court of Arbitration for Sport. The athletes had been charged with avoiding drugs tests in Tel Aviv, Chicago, and Athens as well as failing to notify anti-doping officials of their whereabouts before the Olympics. An independent tribunal ruled that Kenteris and Thanou had not been informed they needed to attend a drug test in Athens; however, their former coach Christos Tzekos was banned for four years. Greek prosecutors still plan to pursue separate charges against the athletes for missing the tests and faking a motorcycle accident to avoid testing at the Athens Games.
stablelm2:1.6b: Wada plans to appeal the acquittal of Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou, unless IAAF does not, as they were cleared of doping charges related to missing dope tests by the Greek Athletics Federation. Wada chairman Dick Pound states that if the federation's ruling is accepted, they will go before the Court of Arbitration for Sport but urges caution. Kenteris' lawyer argues that such appeals only harm governing bodies and strengthen their case. The duo was charged with avoiding drug tests in Tel Aviv, Chicago, and Athens, as well as faking a motorcycle accident to avoid testing at the Olympics. However, an independent tribunal ruled that they were not informed of attending a drugs test in Athens; Kenteris and Thanou still face separate trials by Greek prosecutors for missed tests and falsifying their motorcycle accident claim.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Wada plans to appeal against the acquittal of Olympic athletes Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou, who were cleared by the Greek Athletics Federation of doping charges related to missing dope tests in Tel Aviv, Chicago, and Athens. If the International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) doesn't appeal, Wada will take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Kenteris and Thanou's lawyer criticized Wada chairman Dick Pound's comments, arguing they harm the sporting governing bodies and bolster their case. Independent tribunals ruled that the athletes were uninformed about attending Athens tests; however, Kenteris and Thanou still face separate trials for missing drugs tests and allegedly faking a motorcycle accident during the 2004 Athens Games.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The World Anti-Doping Agency (Wada) plans to appeal the acquittal of Greek athletes Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou on doping charges if the IAAF does not. The Greek Athletics Federation recently cleared them of missing drug tests, but Wada chairman Dick Pound insists on challenging the decision. Kenteris's lawyer criticized Pound's remarks, arguing they undermine sporting authorities. Kenteris and Thanou had been accused of avoiding drug tests before the Olympics and withdrew from the Athens Games after missing a test. An independent tribunal ruled they were not properly informed about the test, but their former coach Christos Tzekos received a four-year ban. The athletes still face separate legal charges in Greece for missing tests and allegedly faking a motorcycle accident to evade testing.
reference: Kenteris and Thanou still have to face trial on charges brought separately by Greek prosecutors of missing the drugs tests and faking a motorcycle accident to avoid testing at the Athens Games.They withdrew from the Athens Games after missing a drugs test at the Olympic village on 12 August.Kenteris, 31, and Thanou, 30, had been charged with avoiding drugs tests in Tel Aviv, Chicago and Athens and failing to notify anti-doping officials of their whereabouts before the Olympics.But an independent tribunal ruled that the duo had not been informed that they needed to attend a drugs test in Athens.The World Anti-Doping Agency (Wada) will appeal against the acquittal of Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou on doping charges, if the IAAF does not.
